title: The Futurists - EPS_290: AI is for Artists with Lauren Ducrey

rawLines.text: i can explain poetry to people all I
want until you have heard a poem and
you've felt in your body you know how
its music how its rhythm how its images
move you it's it's just not going to
stick it's like explaining the beauty of
a song to you you know i I just You just
need to listen to the song you could
dissect the song and then you can There
it is
[Music]
hey there welcome back to the futurists
i'm Rob Tersk and this week I am solo
because my partner Brett King is
traveling around the world as he
frequently does it's great that he does
that because he always brings fresh
novel insights to our show and finds
interesting people for us to interview
this week we're going to get into a
topic I'm thrilled to do um as everybody
on the show knows I'm very interested in
the subject of language storytelling and
how we construct meaning with stories
we've had a number of guests on the show
in the past who've helped us think about
the future of storytelling and in some
cases uh related topics um like the
future of copyright and the use of
copyrighted material to construct
technologies like artificial
intelligence and so on and so this is a
topic that keeps presenting itself
because the way we use language is going
to affect the way we think and that is
going to affect the way we think about
the future so this week it's a great p
privilege for me to introduce you to
Lauren Dukrae and Lauren has two
interesting characteristics that made me
so curious to get to know her lauren is
a poet and she's also worked with
artificial intelligence and in fact
today she's going to talk to us about
the nexus of those two very different
disciplines lauren welcome to the
futurist it's great to see you thank you
so much Rod thanks for having me happy
to have you here tell me first help my
audience understand what is it that you
do and how did you arrive at this
interesting this sort of juncture of
poetry and artificial intelligence uh
unexpectedly I would say first off um
but yes I am I'm a poet now a keynote
speaker and AI designer and I spent
seven years at Google designing the
personalities of conversational agents
like the Google assistant like
Gemini and in parallel I also founded a
program bringing the connective power of
poetry to teams to foster trust and
collaboration and just a more supportive
workplace so poetry is an avocation of
yours that's like some a passion that
you've had absolutely it wasn't
necessarily what Google was hiring you
for it it just happened to be a passion
that you had that informed what you did
yeah i was hired as a creative writer so
that I would say the ability to you know
harness the connective power of language
was there but my title unfortunately at
Google was not to be a poet so I brought
that in myself and was met with a lot of
excitement by people from all different
job types that's it yeah actually that's
a that's an interesting point sorry to
bust in but this is something that um I
I would bet that some portion of our
audience does not know uh we tend to
think of the technology companies as
very engineering dominated that's that's
true that's an accurate characterization
but that isn't the whole story um my
experience working with technology
companies um on the West Coast is that
there are a lot of creative thinkers in
those companies and actually engineers
are creative thinkers though we don't
typically mention that as like their
first characteristic um and as a result
you'll find that many people working in
technology companies on the side they're
writing they're they're they're um
they're doing art uh they're doing
community work uh they're engaging in
other kinds of expressive activities um
and so these are basically very smart
people who happen to be good engineers
and they work in an engineering first
environment um but there's a lot of
untapped creative potential so you
discovered a way to kind of connect with
that no 100% uh thank you for naming
that because that is one of my biggest
takeaways from my time there so to give
you a little bit of context during COVID
obviously like everyone else we went
remote with my team although Google was
rather wellprepared for that there was
still all the anxieties and turmoil of
facing COVID and I wanted to test out
bringing poetry again as this tool for
human connection which I personally knew
it to be but I wanted to try and bring
it into the workplace and so I piloted a
workshop with my team which went really
well and then at Google internally
there's a learning platform and any
employee can bring a program oh cool and
so I did that and people from all job
types signed up engineers the data
analysts the marketers the HR folks
obviously I was I was part of UX ux
tends to be the more I would say artsy
um you know humanities yeah that's as
close as that's as close to art as you
can get in a technology company ux
design right exactly um and I kind of
anticipated the UX folks to show up but
there was this wild um array of
different folks that showed up all with
this glimmer in their eye saying "I get
to be creative here." Oh cool and I get
to reconnect for a lot of people what I
heard was I used to write when I was
younger and then I went to college maybe
continue writing in college but then I
got a job and I stopped and so this was
a way for them to reconnect with that
creative writing you know ability of
theirs and leave this was a second
takeaway that I that I keep very near
and dear to my heart leave feeling
really
energized when you know you could think
like oh you just took an hour out of
your workday to do something unrelated
they left really energized and with a
really important sense of belonging
because I would have them connect not
even through writing poems at first just
discussing poems as this you know as
these creative tables um that allows to
tap into emotion but with that safe
space the poem is kind of doing the is
doing a lot of the work right we're not
asking you like tell me about your life
it's more through this poem what can you
share about yourself with other people
and um and that that sense of human
connection was something that people
were really thirsty for and that's why
they showed up that's really cool and so
um part of your experience I'm I'm
assuming is uh that in in doing that you
discovered
um by let me frame that a little bit
differently by uh helping your
colleagues um reconnect with their
expressive potential and find a vehicle
for
expression you actually unlocked some
superpowers for the company absolutely
this is what I would love for you to
talk a little bit about like you know um
because it's obviously not just
appropriate for Google right you could
do this for almost any organization and
and and in a way it's sort of what you
were just saying you know people get
busy in their lives they may have these
creative pursuits or inclinations but
then work takes over life takes over
family takes over and then the creative
aspirations they're not just put in the
back seat they're put in the trunk of
the car and you forget about them
sometimes they're just left at home on
the journey and then people have regret
you know like midway through their life
they're like gosh I used to be a
creative person whatever happened you
know here I am 30 years later what the
heck happened um so what you learned at
Google could be appropriate for other
companies tell me about that if you
could like what is the takeaway benefit
for the organization totally um and I
will say it definitely is appropriate
for other companies because I actually
left Google last year to dedicate myself
full-time to this work so I have
experienced it with other companies um
and the main benefits I would say is
that poetry is an accelerator to build
trust and collaboration i think those
are two of the main takeaways and I'll
give you an example i led a workshop
with the seauite of a pretty major food
and beverage company and I had been
brought in because they went through a
significant reorg and there were new
hires right so they needed to create
that team cohesion that team trust to be
able to move forward
effectively and what I essentially had
them do was craft their team manifesto
in poetic language m and these people
were not you know they hadn't studied
creative writing you know we had the CFO
in the room that was a very obviously
like numbersorientated
person and what I got to witness was
people discovering their teammates in a
completely new light and some of these
people had worked together for years you
know and I heard like I didn't know that
you loved this or that you know had this
point of view on a thing right so
discovering their teammates completely a
really understanding the unique value
that everybody brought into the room
some of the feedback at the end was
beautiful it was truly like I now
understand what everybody in this team
brings to the table i have renewed
empathy for my co-workers okay that's a
magnificent discovery did did you
actually ask them to write poetry or
were they using um you so simile and
metaphor and symbology or maybe they
were using meter uh and rhythm and rhyme
so I scaffolded things right obviously
to give people you know kind of like
guard rails to work with so that they I
wasn't just throwing them off the deep
end and we worked as our inspiration uh
with a beautiful poem by Mary Oliver
called The Journey um which really
captures the the initial struggles of
you know stepping out from your comfort
zone to build something new to go and
like find purpose and then eventually
the process of finding it so we use that
poem as our inspiration and then I had
them basically write in kind of a mad
lib structure so we used the basic
structure of the poem and I just had
them replace some of the words so when
the poem was talking about obstacles
they had to represent like a metaphor
for their
obstacles when the poem spoke about the
speaker in the poem finding their
purpose I invited everybody to find like
what is your metaphor within the team
you know are you the and we use the
metaphor of the journey so I was like
are you the map maker are you the
binoculars are you the mountain in the
distance are you the walking shoes
that's cool so using metaphor as a just
a very simple distillation of poetic
language cuz yes I think people can hear
poetry and they're like "Wait but I what
i can't write a poem." I'm like "No
let's start simple just images and
metaphors." I love that idea uh I'm um
as you can see from the pictures behind
me I'm a painter and I I draw and the
way we're taught to do art at least the
way we used to be taught to do art is to
uh mimic the work or study the work of
great artists and um and of course you
do that in writing you you read you'll
you'll read all the great poets and the
great writers of course to learn how to
write yourself but I've never heard
anyone do that like deconstruct a poem
and replace parts it it makes perfect
sense because then you don't have to
struggle with things like meter and
rhythm um you know and actually even
beyond that um just swapping out parts
the way you're describing it it also
allows everybody to focus on the same
poem so you don't have to contend with
everybody reading their own individual
poem and then everyone in the room
trying to figure out what they're
talking about that could take an
enormous amount of time so it's a little
bit more time efficient to work this way
with everyone focused on the same
structure yeah I think there's there's
definitely that point of efficiency i
also wanted them to collectively write a
poem that would also capture their
individual contributions and that's
that's really important to me in these
um sessions that are focused on trust
building and collaboration and another
reason for bringing in the poem quite
early on was also just to give them a
direct lived experience of poetic
language because I can explain poetry to
people all I want until you have heard a
poem and you've felt in your body you
know how its music how its rhythm how
its images move you it's it's just not
going to stick it's like explaining the
beauty of a song to you you know I I
just you just need to listen to the song
you could dissect the song and then you
kind of There it is exactly we we I
think working helping people deal with
um metaphor and analogy I think it's a I
think it's a really powerful thing it's
a noble undertaking because we live in a
very literal society people are very
very very literal um and um and and I
hate to say uncreative because there is
tremendous amount of innovation
happening around us but it's always in
the service of something else you know
so it's never art for art's sake it's
never um you know the the magic of
comparing something that you've observed
with something that we already know and
thereby discovering a connection that
perhaps wasn't evident uh it's not about
that idea that spirit of discovery and
and um and the kind of joy of expression
instead it's always in the service of
something else you know so for instance
uh poet anyone with poetic imagination
in a corporation would typically be in
the marketing department yes banging out
marketing copy or social media marketing
and it's like oh gosh that is like using
a um Maserati to move furniture it's
just a terrible use of that skill and I
can imagine that person feels soulless
when they go home and that's like this
is not what I was put on this planet to
do right um so
do you run into literalism like do you
run into people who have a inability to
think in metaphor or think about an
analogy do you do you find that some
people have that problem that's a really
good
question so far I truly have not
then you may be teaching me a great
technique that I can use because I I do
run into this quite frequently uh where
I'm dealing with people and half the
people are speaking metaphorically and
the other half of the people literally
do not understand them right they're
like "Wait what how where do you you
just took the conversation into this
weird place i can follow it i like it i
think it's helpful but for some people
they don't find it helpful they find it
confusing i mean I think that there's
just truth to that and meeting people
where they are is always deeply
important to me like as as an educator
as a as a workshop facilitator and it's
maybe introducing to people the
metaphors that are already in their life
that they don't even realize i mean in
the corporate world they're used all the
time you know maybe people don't
resonate with these either you know like
drinking from the fire hose building the
plane while you or flying the plane
while you build it building the plane
while you fly it that's the one um and
maybe you know that's a way in all over
the place yeah that's true we use those
kinds of metaphor they're very good
examples you just gave uh it's true you
know oh we're the airplane's taxiing
down the runway and we're trying to
change the engine and you know that's
like a a reference to making design
changes at a last minute for a product
that's about to launch for instance or
you know changing the engine while the
airplane is in the air another example
you know we've already deployed a
service on the web and we have to swap
out some microservices how do we keep
the thing going you know but that's a
boring way of saying it so instead we
use this colorful metaphor and people
seem to understand that but those have
now become so overused yes so shopworn
so threadbear that they we don't even
think of their metaphorical power
anymore we just they they just become a
substitute for an idea right they're
like a shortorthhand if you will exactly
uh so in a way that's um the opposite
function right because the function of
metaphor or analogy is to cause you to
see something a fresh to cause you to
see something in a new way to cause you
to make a new connection a novel
connection hadn't occurred to you before
that's the vitality in poetry that's the
function of poetry um when we use these
cliche terms it's the exact opposite
what we're doing is we're shortcutting
we're sparing ourselves the cognitive
effort of having to make the connection
ourselves um we're sparing ourselves the
words to actually describe the real
situation so instead we substitute this
commonly understood metaphor that
everybody gets and we can just all move
on uh it's a kind of group think but
often I think it's dangerous because it
causes people to overlook the complexity
of the situation when we talk about it
with stereotypical terms we're actually
failing to describe it accurately and
it's like it's oified what it's trying
to describe and that what was once true
is no longer true so you're you're
missing out absolutely yeah you're
reminding me of George Orwell's essay
The Politics in the English Language
which I've been reading lately because
if if you're curious about what's
happening in the federal government in
the United States right now this is a
great time to read George Orwell's
essays i'm not talking about the book
1984 or the other book Animal Farm his
essays he was first and foremost an
essayist and he wrote about the use of
language and he wrote about these kinds
of shortcuts that people make where they
substitute a block of words for original
thinking and he talks about shopworn
metaphors uh that are substitute for
original thought and what they do to
people's ability to think because this
is the thing about language you know
language is an operating system for
society right language is how we
construct meaning it's how we express
meaning if you're using if you're just
stringing together a bunch of cliches
you're not really thinking um gosh that
certainly wasn't what you expected to be
talking about this morning for this call
i'm not I'm not that surprised and I I
actually you know I think we know that
language shapes you know how we think
and I would even go one step further it
also shapes how we feel and I know that
that can seem counterintuitive and that
the lived experience might seem like oh
I have an emotion right i feel like heat
in my chest or my cheeks are flushed and
then I name
that excitement anger stress you know
whatever whatever that is for you but
there's actually really fascinating
research that to me um is an argument
for getting more creative or curious
about poetic language the research is by
Lisa Feldman Barrett and the her major
book is called How Emotions Are Made and
she basically like flips the view that
we all have universal emotions that they
all show up the same way phys
physiologically neurologically and that
actually we construct emotions in
reaction to certain
circumstances and that the language that
we use to name certain emotions has a
huge impact on how we con how we
construct them so if we're used to
calling you know a certain emotional
feeling sadness but we're not
differentiating
between soft sadness or like let's say
melancholy and then you're more passing
like nostalgia you might actually be
lumping together very different
experiences and then that takes away
your ability to have self-awareness
about oh I know what this is actually
nostalgia this is actually melancholy
and I respond to those in different ways
so it's what she says the more granular
your language the better your
self-awareness and also the better your
ability to choose how you respond
emotionally in different instances
that's very powerful insight yeah that's
really that resonates with me on a
personal level but I'm actually thinking
in the in terms of the corporation once
again you know when when uh
relationships get intense in companies
and they often do people disagree
vehemently and sometimes emotionally but
they can't uh it's a little perplexing
right if you're looking at uh from the
outside if you're looking at an
organization from the outside say as a
consultant or an adviser it's a little
perplexing and people get so emotional
it's like this business like why is this
personal to you why are you getting But
part of the problem is that people
cannot name their emotions they're not
able to put a label on what they're
feeling um or they're being confronted
with information that so challenges what
they hold dear in themselves maybe uh
concepts that are so integral to
themselves they haven't articulated them
so they can't put a name on that what
they truly believe or what they stand
for that it feels like a threat to their
identity which feels like an attack and
so they respond as if they're being
attacked i see this happen frequently
and I often wonder about it myself uh a
therapist and I had a conversation about
this and she pointed out that men in
particular are unable to name emotions
and of course I said I'm a man I said no
kidding and we talked about it but in
five minutes she revealed to me that in
fact it was true for me I don't know if
it's true for all men but certainly for
me and that set me off on a journey to
understand this better because I
discovered that the way I was raised uh
at least uh if you're a boy you're not
meant to feel certain feelings and
you're certainly not meant to express
them it's like "Come on be a big boy."
Um played football it's like "You're not
hurt get back out there on the field i'm
not hurt." Okay so you you start to
repress even you know physical
sensations
and as a result uh as an adult you have
a very hard time articulating an
emotional set of circumstances and when
you can't articulate what's going on yes
you can't form think thoughts about it
right and if you can't form thoughts
about it then you're not going to be
able to devise an action plan or
coherent uh uh you know you're not able
to process it in a way where you can
take a reasonable action and that is how
people respond in irrational ways
unfortunately this seems like something
that's spreading through the whole world
right now and when you read the
newspaper every morning you're like "Oh
here's more examples of irrational
thinking people concocting these
elaborate narratives." Yeah that aren't
really based in reality um because they
can't confront what's actually happening
within themselves and I think that
self-awareness piece is one that I'm
deeply passionate about in the use of
poetry i always say that poets poems are
mirrors for us to better see ourselves
because they do this they do this
amazing thing where they're made of
language which is something that we all
use right and I adore paintings I adore
music I adore all the art forms but
poems are made of language this like
rational construct that we all
use but they use it to go beyond
language they kind of flip language on
its head right they put words together
that you would never have expected to
see or they create a musical rhythm that
goes beyond language to evoke and elicit
your emotions your imagination and your
intuition and so when you're reading a
poem again you have this easy entry to
it it's like okay it's language let me
read this and then it's going to it's
going to trigger you in some way or
another it might be you know not liking
the poem because you don't understand
what it means or it might be a deep
sense of delight for this one metaphor
whatever emotional reaction you're
having you can then come back to the
poem and go back to this familiar thing
that's language to start and unpack that
reaction that you had and realize like
oh yeah there's no punctuation in this
poem that's really annoying to me
because I like when things are
structured or this one image of you know
the dog on the corner of a street
reminded me of my childhood when D and
suddenly you're able to to have a much
more intimate relationship with that
emotion and you might not even be naming
it yet right you don't need to name that
it's nostalgia or joy or whatever it is
but it it gives us this like first
doorway and that's what I see when I
work with poems it's like okay can we
just use them to understand like what's
what's going on with us and then the
poem becomes this proxy to talk about
ourselves which can again be a little
bit easier than you know you mentioned
therapy can be challenging because it's
you're truly being asked to like talk
about yourself in a pretty clear way
here the poem becomes a bridge again
between all these emotions this
intuition that's below the surface and
your rational logical mind and that
bridge is is language
I love the conversation but I'm so
curious as we're talking what's in the
back of my mind right now as I listen
thinking how do you present this to
companies like who is it that you sell
this proposition to and what is it that
they think they're buying when they hire
you to come to their company and do this
for them so that's a great question
um so I introduce myself as a poet but
also as an AI designer and um that
intersection to me is also it's very
dear i think it's uncanny again that I I
came from the world of literature was
hired into a tech company to design
these AI tools and was at the forefront
and still am at the forefront of you
know designing large language models i'm
like okay there's there's something
about language here so I always
introduce myself as a poet and as an AI
designer but what I really emphasize on
is empathetic communication and like how
can we use our language in an era where
AI is also based on language to unlock
skills that AI cannot
replace typically our emotional
intelligence super and to me one of the
biggest I would say tools to develop
your emotional intelligence is your
language is your are your communication
abilities maybe the only way right you
can demonstrate it through actions but
that's that's pretty intangible exactly
because again like we said the words you
use they're going to impact how you
think about yourself how you think about
your emotions how you manage your
emotions and then those words are also
going to help you connect with other
people understand how other people are
thinking and feeling to create those you
know healthy work relationships that you
need to get to your you know your goal
your project goals your deadlines to
talk to your leadership and pitch an
idea so I focus on how we can or how
important it is to master empathetic
communication to thrive in this age of
AI and then I'll use in certain cases
poetry and AI poetry or AI depending on
how comfortable the organization is it
really varies some companies are quite
open to the more artistic angle because
they know that it just gets people into
a state of presence and in that growth
mindset that you want and sometimes the
entry point is AI and I'll have people
actually use large language models to
prepare for difficult conversations that
has been one of the big topics that I've
been I've been pushing and talking about
great topic and you brought us right up
to the brink of artificial intelligence
which we definitely want to get into but
now we have to take a little break so
folks uh you're listening to the
futurists i'm Rob Chersik and this is my
guest Lauren Dukrae who is a poet who's
an expert in artificial intelligence and
we're going to learn more about the
intersection of language and artificial
intelligence right after the break don't
go away we'll be right
back hey there welcome back to the
futurists i'm Rob Tersik and this week
I'm interviewing a poet who knows about
artificial intelligence uh Lauren Drae
thank you very much for joining the
futurist this week so one of the things
our audience may not know but they
should if they check out your bio at
laurenrae.com they'll learn more about
your background um because your
presentation on your website is in both
French and English and so these are two
sides of your personality now as we're
talking right now you seem like a very
typical American person a a thoughtful
American but we could be having this
conversation in French or you could
probably not me tell me a little bit
about being raised bilingual
happily um it is I think it is the first
of the two hats that I've kind of worn
uh my whole life so my mom's American my
dad is French and I very much grew up at
the intersection of two cultures two
languages my parents did a terrific job
at really uh not just conveying language
to us but truly uh
culture
and I think that allowed me to develop
at a pretty young age an appreciation
for the many different points of view
that exist on reality not to get too
philosophical but I actually give you a
very specific example so I'd spend my
summers in the States visiting American
family before going back to Paris where
I went to school and I discovered
chipmunks one summer and decided that
chipmunks were my favorite animal being
so incredibly adorable and so I was very
excited to come home to my school
friends and tell them all about
chipmunks and then I got to school and I
was like I don't know how to say
chipmunk in French so I went home and I
asked my parents and they didn't really
know they were like there actually isn't
really a word for chipmunk and I there's
no in France because there are no
chipmunks in France and I remember
having a just a mind-blowing I was maybe
6 years old having this mindblowing aha
moment that language you know reflects
different realities but therefore
there's not perfect parody between
languages and that that just stuck with
me and and my my bilingualism has
definitely been a a guiding light in my
career and in my work it is quite
interesting how learning a different
language causes you to to understand you
have this sort of flash of insight that
the people who speak that language
natively actually construct meaning
differently yes and different languages
function in different ways of course
English is inflected with so much French
there's a blending there right a lot of
French linguistic concepts are buried in
English or embedded in English um when I
learned German I was really struck
because German uh has very precise
grammar rules and you can reorganize
words and you can take participles and
move them around and it actually changes
the meaning of the word you can build
new words with it and it struck me at
the time that and Japanese seems to work
in a similar principle it's no surprise
those two countries are great at
engineering and I know I'm making a
gross generalization right now but it's
uh the language ability allows you to to
sort of understand how to construct
things and move things around and I
think that does actually express itself
in national character maybe I'm on the
brink of making generalizations that
aren't going to be very supportive so I
could probably pull back from that but
inviting you to chime in and opine on
the subject
now this brings to mind two examples
that I love um one is relative to the
structure of different languages so
French typically has you know a subject
verb complement rest of the sentence
versus German that has the verb at the
way end of a sentence and the impact
that that has in conversation is that
it's very easy to interrupt in French
because you get so much substance at the
very beginning of a sentence whereas in
German you have to wait until the end of
a sentence and so you can't interrupt
and so you'll have these different
discursive and conversational styles in
